description.short: Methodology of creating, storing, and reusing pre-crafted, optimized prompts for recurring AI tasks to ensure consistency and save time
description.detailed: Custom Prompt Templates is a productivity methodology where users create libraries of carefully crafted, tested prompts for recurring tasks with AI assistants (ChatGPT, Claude, Copilot, etc.). Instead of writing prompts from scratch each time, users maintain a personal or team collection of optimized templates with placeholders for variable inputs. Templates include context, desired format, tone, constraints, and examples. Advanced practitioners organize templates by category (writing, analysis, coding, etc.), version them, and share with teams. This approach transforms ad-hoc AI usage into systematic, repeatable workflows with consistent quality.
description.primary_function: Systematize and optimize recurring AI interactions through reusable, tested prompt templates
key_capabilities: Create reusable prompt structures for recurring tasks
Store templates in accessible format (Notion, Google Docs, etc.)
Parameterize prompts with placeholders for variable inputs
Version and iterate on prompt quality over time
Share templates across teams for consistency
Organize by category/use case for quick discovery
Include examples and expected outputs in templates
Track performance metrics for continuous improvement
Build prompt chains for multi-step workflows

components: Role/Persona: Define AI's role (e.g., 'You are an expert product manager...')
Context: Background information needed for task
Task Description: Specific action to perform
Format/Structure: Desired output format (bullet points, table, markdown, etc.)
Tone/Style: Communication style (formal, casual, technical, etc.)
template_structure.example_template:
You are an expert product manager at a SaaS company.

Task: Prepare me for an upcoming meeting with [STAKEHOLDER_NAME] about [TOPIC].

Context:
- Stakeholder role: [ROLE]
- Meeting goal: [GOAL]
- My objectives: [OBJECTIVES]

Provide:
1. Key talking points (5-7 bullets)
2. Potential objections and counter-arguments
3. Questions to ask
4. Success criteria for the meeting

Format: Structured markdown with clear sections.
Tone: Professional but conversational.

organization_methods: Category-based folders (Writing, Analysis, Coding, Research, etc.)
Use case hierarchy (Marketing > Social Media > LinkedIn Post)
storage_solutions: Notion database with tags and search
Claude Projects or ChatGPT custom instructions (platform-native)

getting_started.step_1: Identify 3-5 recurring AI tasks you perform weekly
getting_started.step_2: Document your best prompt for each task
getting_started.step_3: Parameterize with placeholders (replace specific details with [VARIABLES])
getting_started.step_4: Store in accessible location (Notion, Google Docs, etc.)
getting_started.step_5: Test and iterate based on results
getting_started.step_6: Share with team and gather feedback

template_development_workflow: Start with specific prompt for one instance
Generalize by replacing specifics with parameters
Iterate to v2.0 based on collective learning
maintenance: Update templates when AI models improve (prompts may need adjustment)
Track which templates save most time (prioritize optimization)
Add new templates as new use cases emerge

prompt_design: Start simple, add complexity only if needed
Specify output format explicitly (JSON, markdown, bullet points, etc.)
Include constraints to prevent scope creep
Test with diverse inputs before sharing with team
organization: Use consistent naming convention (verb-noun format, e.g., 'Analyze-CompetitorProduct')
Tag with metadata (department, use case, frequency, difficulty)
Create README or index document for team discovery
Include 'last tested' date to flag potentially outdated templates
Link related templates (e.g., 'Prepare Meeting' â†’ 'Summarize Meeting')
team_adoption: Start with 3-5 highest-impact templates (prove value quickly)
Share success stories ('This template saved me 2 hours!')
Make templates easily discoverable (single source of truth)
Schedule quarterly review sessions to refine templates
Track usage metrics if possible (which templates most valuable)

known_limitations: Templates can become outdated as AI models evolve
Over-templating can reduce creativity and exploration
Requires initial time investment to build library
May not cover all edge cases (custom prompts still needed)
Team adoption requires cultural shift (documentation discipline)
Effectiveness depends on prompt engineering skill
limitations.best_for: Knowledge workers who regularly use AI assistants, teams seeking consistency, people with recurring AI tasks
limitations.not_ideal_for: One-off tasks, highly exploratory/creative work with no patterns, individuals uncomfortable with structured processes

meeting_preparation.name: Prepare for Stakeholder Meeting
meeting_preparation.prompt:
You are an expert product manager. Prepare me for a meeting with [STAKEHOLDER_NAME], who is a [STAKEHOLDER_ROLE].

Meeting context:
- Topic: [TOPIC]
- My objectives: [OBJECTIVES]
- Known stakeholder concerns: [CONCERNS]

Provide:
1. Key talking points (5-7 bullets)
2. Potential objections and responses
3. Questions to ask
4. Meeting success criteria
5. Follow-up actions to propose

Format: Markdown with clear sections.

decision_documentation.name: Document Decision with Principles
decision_documentation.prompt:
You are a strategic advisor. Help me document this decision:

Decision: [DECISION]
Context: [CONTEXT]
Options considered: [OPTIONS]

Structure the decision memo with:
1. Executive summary (2-3 sentences)
2. Decision principles applied (explicit criteria used)
3. Options analysis (pros/cons for each)
4. Recommendation with rationale
5. Risks and mitigations
6. Success metrics

Format: Professional memo style, 1-2 pages.

code_review.name: Review Code for Security Issues
code_review.prompt:
You are a senior security engineer. Review this code for security vulnerabilities:

```[LANGUAGE]
[CODE]
```

Analyze for:
1. Injection vulnerabilities (SQL, XSS, command injection)
2. Authentication/authorization issues
3. Sensitive data exposure
4. Insecure dependencies
5. OWASP Top 10 risks

For each issue found:
- Severity (Critical/High/Medium/Low)
- Description
- Specific code location
- Remediation recommendation

Format: Markdown table with columns: Severity, Issue, Location, Remediation.
